elements.content: The reactions of AgNO3 with Na2L and Mg(HL)2 (H2L = 5-sulfosalicylic acid) gave two luminescent coordination polymers:  Ag2L(H2O) (1) and [Ag2(HL)2(H2O)3]H2O (2), respectively. 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P2/n, with a = 7.489(2), b = 16.237(3), c = 8.222(2) Å, β = 92.90(3)°, V = 998.5(3) Å3, Z = 4. Compound 1 is the first silver carboxylate-sulfonate with an extended three-dimensional structure, a framework composed of four kinds of crystallographically unique silver atoms and organic species with three different functional groups, carboxylic, hydroxyl, and sulfonic, each coordinated to the silver atoms. 2 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̄, with a = 8.307(2), b = 11.246(2), c = 12.590(3) Å, α =112.68(3), β = 97.66(3), γ = 95.51(3)°, V = 1061.6(4) Å3, Z = 2. In 2, silver ions are bridged by sulfonate groups to form one-dimensional chains, and each chain is connected to the two neighboring chains through the coordination of the carbonyl oxygen atoms to the silver ions of the neighboring polymeric chain to form a two-dimensional network. The luminescent properties of the two compounds are also discussed.
elements.clean_text: The reactions of AgNO3 with Na2L and Mg(HL)2 (H2L = 5-sulfosalicylic acid) gave two luminescent coordination polymers: Ag2L(H2O) (1) and [Ag2(HL)2(H2O)3]H2O (2), respectively. 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P2/n, with a = 7.489(2), b = 16.237(3), c = 8.222(2) Å, β = 92.90(3)°, V = 998.5(3) Å3, Z = 4. Compound 1 is the first silver carboxylate-sulfonate with an extended three-dimensional structure, a framework composed of four kinds of crystallographically unique silver atoms and organic species with three different functional groups, carboxylic, hydroxyl, and sulfonic, each coordinated to the silver atoms. 2 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̄, with a = 8.307(2), b = 11.246(2), c = 12.590(3) Å, α =112.68(3), β = 97.66(3), γ = 95.51(3)°, V = 1061.6(4) Å3, Z = 2. In 2, silver ions are bridged by sulfonate groups to form one-dimensional chains, and each chain is connected to the two neighboring chains through the coordination of the carbonyl oxygen atoms to the silver ions of the neighboring polymeric chain to form a two-dimensional network. The luminescent properties of the two compounds are also discussed.

elements.content: The reaction of AgNO3 with deprotonated 5-sulfosalicylic acid gave two luminescent coordination polymers, one of which is the first silver carboxylate-sulfonate with an extended three-dimensional structure, a framework composed of silver atoms and organic species with three different functional groups, carboxylic, hydroxyl, and sulfonic, each coordinated to the silver atoms.
elements.clean_text: The reaction of AgNO3 with deprotonated 5-sulfosalicylic acid gave two luminescent coordination polymers, one of which is the first silver carboxylate-sulfonate with an extended three-dimensional structure, a framework composed of silver atoms and organic species with three different functional groups, carboxylic, hydroxyl, and sulfonic, each coordinated to the silver atoms.

elements.content: The assembly of multifunctional ligands with metal ions is currently of great interest due to their use in constructing two- and three-dimensional polymers with special properties, such as electrical conductivity, magnetism, host−guest chemistry, and catalysis. So far, most of these materials are formed with N-containing ligands, such as 4,4‘-bipyridine and pyrazine. Polycarboxylic, polyalcohols, and polyethers, polyphosphonic acid, and sulfonic acid1c have also been used for the construction of coordination polymers. Some studies on ligands containing different coordinating groups have been reported, and we are interested in the coordination polymers containing such kinds of ligands. On the basis of its structure (Scheme ), 5-sulfosalicylic acid (H2L) has three potential coordinating groups -OH, -CO2H, and -SO3H. Both -CO2H and -SO3H are versatile coordinating groups and can coordinate to metal in a variety of modes. (Schemes and )
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The assembly of multifunctional ligands with metal ions is currently of great interest due to their use in constructing two- and three-dimensional polymers with special properties, such as electrical conductivity, magnetism, host-guest chemistry, and catalysis. So far, most of these materials are formed with N-containing ligands, such as 4,4‘-bipyridine and pyrazine. Polycarboxylic, polyalcohols, and polyethers, polyphosphonic acid, and sulfonic acid1c have also been used for the construction of coordination polymers. Some studies on ligands containing different coordinating groups have been reported, and we are interested in the coordination polymers containing such kinds of ligands. On the basis of its structure (Scheme ), 5-sulfosalicylic acid (H2L) has three potential coordinating groups -OH, -CO2H, and -SO3H. Both -CO2H and -SO3H are versatile coordinating groups and can coordinate to metal in a variety of modes. (Schemes  and )

elements.content: Some studies on the interesting coordination of silver sulfonates and their solid-state properties have been reported. Silver benzenesulfonate, silver p-toluenesulfonate, and silver p-chlorobenzenesulfonate15 show layered structures, in which silver ions are bridged by SO3 groups to form polymeric layers, and the organic moieties of the sulfonates protrude into the interlayer space. If the phenyl ring of benzenesulfonate is modified by other coordinating functional groups, the silver sulfonate is expected to have a novel three-dimensional framework. In this paper, the silver compounds Ag2L(H2O) (1) and [Ag2(HL)2(H2O)3]H2O (2) have been synthesized. 1 shows an interesting three-dimensional polymeric structure, in which each of the three different functional groups, carboxylic, hydroxyl, and sulfonic, is coordinated to the silver atoms. In 2, silver ions are bridged by sulfonate groups to form one-dimensional chains.
elements.clean_text: Some studies on the interesting coordination of silver sulfonates and their solid-state properties have been reported. Silver benzenesulfonate, silver p-toluenesulfonate, and silver p-chlorobenzenesulfonate15 show layered structures, in which silver ions are bridged by SO3 groups to form polymeric layers, and the organic moieties of the sulfonates protrude into the interlayer space. If the phenyl ring of benzenesulfonate is modified by other coordinating functional groups, the silver sulfonate is expected to have a novel three-dimensional framework. In this paper, the silver compounds Ag2L(H2O) (1) and [Ag2(HL)2(H2O)3]H2O (2) have been synthesized. 1 shows an interesting three-dimensional polymeric structure, in which each of the three different functional groups, carboxylic, hydroxyl, and sulfonic, is coordinated to the silver atoms. In 2, silver ions are bridged by sulfonate groups to form one-dimensional chains.

elements.content:
Materials. All reagents and solvents for syntheses were purchased from commercial sources and used as received.

Physical Methods. A Perkin-Elmer 240 elemental analyzer was used to collect microanalytical data, and the FT-IR spectrum was recorded from KBr pellets in range 4000−400 cm-1 on a Mattson Alpha-Centauri spectrometer. The emission spectra were recorded on a Varian Cary Eclipse spectrometer. The absorption spectra were recorded on a Varian Cary 500 spectrometer. The luminescence decay was recorded with a SPEX 1934D spectrometer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

 Materials. All reagents and solvents for syntheses were purchased from commercial sources and used as received. 

 Physical Methods. A Perkin-Elmer 240 elemental analyzer was used to collect microanalytical data, and the FT-IR spectrum was recorded from KBr pellets in range 4000-400 cm-1 on a Mattson Alpha-Centauri spectrometer. The emission spectra were recorded on a Varian Cary Eclipse spectrometer. The absorption spectra were recorded on a Varian Cary 500  spectrometer. The luminescence decay was recorded with a SPEX 1934D spectrometer.

elements.content: Synthesis of Ag 2 L(H 2 O) (1). To a mixture of H2L (0.11 g, 0.5 mmol) and NaOH (0.040 g, 1.0 mmol) in water (5 mL), a solution of AgNO3 (0.170 g, 1.0 mmol) in water (10 mL) was added. After the sample was stirred for 30 min, the solution was filtered. Colorless crystals of 1 were obtained after the filtrate was left at room temperature for several days. The crystals were collected and washed with water and dried in air (0.16 g). Elemental analysis calcd for C7H6Ag2O7S:  C 18.69, H 1.34; found:  C 18.51, H 1.30. IR (cm-1):  3432 s (-OH), 1562 m (νas CO2), 1436 s (νs CO2), 1034 s (ν3 S−O).

After the sample was stirred for 30 min, the solution was filtered. Colorless crystals of 1 were obtained after the filtrate was left at room temperature for several days. The crystals were collected and washed with water and dried in air (0.16 g). Elemental analysis calcd for C7H6Ag2O7S: C 18.69, H 1.34; found: C 18.51, H 1.30. IR (cm-1): 3432 s (-OH), 1562 m (νas CO2), 1436 s (νs CO2), 1034 s (ν3 S-O).

elements.content: Synthesis of [Ag 2 (HL) 2 (H 2 O) 3 ]H 2 O (2). To a solution of H2L (0.22 g, 1.0 mmol) and MgO (0.020 g, 0.5 mmol) in water (5 mL), a solution of AgNO3 (0.170 g, 1.0 mmol) in water (10 mL) was added. After the sample was stirred for 30 min, the solution was filtered. Colorless crystals of 2 were obtained after the filtrate was left at room temperature for several days. The crystals were collected and washed with water and dried in air (0.27 g). Elemental analysis calcd for C14H18Ag2O16S2:  C 23.29, H 2.51; found:  C 22.91, H 2.40. IR (cm-1):  3408 s (-OH), 1656 m (-CO2H), 1021 s (ν3 S−O).
elements.clean_text: Synthesis of [Ag  2  (HL)  2  (H  2  O)  3  ]H  2  O (2). To a solution of H2L (0.22 g, 1.0 mmol) and MgO (0.020 g, 0.5 mmol) in water (5 mL), a solution of AgNO3 (0.170 g, 1.0 mmol) in water (10 mL) was added. After the sample was stirred for 30 min, the solution was filtered. Colorless crystals of 2 were obtained after the filtrate was left at room temperature for several days. The crystals were collected and washed with water and dried in air (0.27 g). Elemental analysis calcd for C14H18Ag2O16S2: C 23.29, H 2.51; found: C 22.91, H 2.40. IR (cm-1): 3408 s (-OH), 1656 m (-CO2H), 1021 s (ν3 S-O).

elements.content: X-ray Crystallography. Experimental details of the X-ray analyses are provided in Table . Diffraction intensities for compounds 1 and 2 were collected on a Rigaku RAXIS−RAPID image plate diffractometer using ω scan technique with MoKα radiation (λ = 0.71069Å). Absorption corrections were applied using a multiscan technique. The structures were solved with the direct method of SHELXS-9721 and refined with full-matrix least-squares techniques using the SHELXL-97 program22 within WINGX. Non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms attached to carbon were generated geometrically, while the aqua hydrogen atoms were not located. Analytical expression of neutral-atom scattering factors were employed, and anomalous dispersion corrections were incorporated. Further details are provided in Supporting Information.
elements.clean_text: X-ray Crystallography. Experimental details of the X-ray analyses are provided in Table . Diffraction intensities for compounds 1 and 2 were collected on a Rigaku RAXIS-RAPID image plate diffractometer using ω scan technique with MoKα radiation (λ = 0.71069Å). Absorption corrections were applied using a multiscan technique. The structures were solved with the direct method of SHELXS-9721 and refined with full-matrix least-squares techniques using the SHELXL-97 program22 within WINGX. Non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms attached to carbon were generated geometrically, while the aqua hydrogen atoms were not located. Analytical expression of neutral-atom scattering factors were employed, and anomalous dispersion corrections were incorporated. Further details are provided in Supporting Information.

Selected bond distances and angles for compounds 1 and 2 are listed in Table . The colorless crystals of 1 were obtained by a reaction of AgNO3 with Na2L in water. In 1, -SO3H and -CO2H groups are deprotonated, but -OH groups are neutral. There is one kind of crystallographically unique L2- anions in the structure. As shown in Figure , each sulfonate group forms binds to five different silver ions, with two oxygen atoms each binding to two different silver ions while the remaining oxygen atom binds to only a single silver ion, and this is a highly unusual coordination mode for a R−SO3 - anion. Each carboxylate group acts as a bridging ligand to join two silver ions, which are connnected by a Ag−Ag bond, with either carboxylate oxygen atom binding to one silver ion. Each hydroxyl group is coordinated to one silver ion. Thus, each L2- group binds to eight silver ions in all.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Selected bond distances and angles for compounds 1 and 2 are listed in Table . The colorless crystals of 1 were obtained by a reaction of AgNO3 with Na2L in water. In 1, -SO3H and -CO2H groups are deprotonated, but -OH groups are neutral. There is one kind of crystallographically unique L2- anions in the structure. As shown in Figure , each sulfonate group forms binds to five different silver ions, with two oxygen atoms each binding to two different silver ions while the remaining  oxygen atom binds to only a single silver ion, and this is a highly unusual coordination mode for a R-SO3 - anion. Each carboxylate group acts as a bridging ligand to join two silver ions, which are connnected by a Ag-Ag bond, with either carboxylate oxygen atom binding to one silver ion. Each hydroxyl group is coordinated to one silver ion. Thus, each L2- group binds to eight silver ions in all.

There exist four kinds of crystallographically unique silver ions in 1. Ag1 is coordinated by two carboxylate oxygen atoms and two hydroxyl oxygen atoms from four different L2- groups while Ag2 is coordinated by two carboxylate oxygen atoms and two sulfonate oxygen atoms from four different L2- groups (Figure ). Ag1 and Ag2 are bridged by two μ2-carboxylate groups, and there exists a strong binding action between Ag1 and Ag2 with the Ag−Ag distance of 2.78 Å. Ag3 and Ag4 have similar a coordination sphere, with either silver atom binding to two water molecules and four sulfonate oxygen atoms from four differnet L2- groups (Figure ). The distances of Ag3 or Ag4 to neighboring silver ions are larger than 3.7 Å, indicating there is no Ag−Ag binding for them.
elements.clean_text: There exist four kinds of crystallographically unique silver ions in 1. Ag1 is coordinated by two carboxylate oxygen atoms and two hydroxyl oxygen atoms from four different L2- groups while Ag2 is coordinated by two carboxylate oxygen atoms and two sulfonate oxygen atoms from four different L2- groups (Figure ). Ag1 and Ag2 are bridged by two μ2-carboxylate groups, and there exists a strong binding action between Ag1 and Ag2 with the Ag-Ag distance of 2.78 Å. Ag3 and Ag4 have similar a coordination sphere, with either silver atom binding to two water molecules and four sulfonate oxygen atoms from four differnet L2- groups (Figure ). The distances of Ag3 or Ag4 to neighboring silver ions are larger than 3.7 Å, indicating there is no Ag-Ag binding for them.

elements.content: As the layered structure of the reported silver sulfonates, in the crystal structure of 1, silver ions (Ag3, Ag4) are bridged by SO3 groups to form polymeric layers (Figure ), with the organic moieties of the sulfonates directing into the interlayer space. As shown in Figure , the dimeric units [Ag2]2+ (Ag1, Ag2) are intercalated into the space between the organic groups from the same polymeric layer, with each [Ag2]2+ unit binding to two μ2-carboxylate groups and two sulfonate oxygen atoms from the polymeric layer. The interlayer distance, defined as the perpendicular distance between planes of silver ion (Ag3, Ag4), of 16.24 Å is slightly longer than those of silver benzenesulfonate (15.23 Å)13 and silver p-toluenesulfonate (15.31 Å). Each [Ag2]2+ unit is also bonded to two hydroxyl groups from the adjacent layers to result in a three-dimensional framework structure.
elements.clean_text: As the layered structure of the reported silver sulfonates, in the crystal structure of 1, silver ions (Ag3, Ag4) are bridged by SO3 groups to form polymeric layers (Figure ), with the organic moieties of the  sulfonates directing into the interlayer space. As shown in Figure , the dimeric units [Ag2]2+ (Ag1, Ag2) are intercalated into the space between the organic groups from the same polymeric layer, with each [Ag2]2+ unit binding to two μ2-carboxylate groups and two sulfonate oxygen atoms from the polymeric layer. The interlayer distance, defined as the perpendicular distance between planes of silver ion (Ag3, Ag4), of 16.24 Å is slightly longer than those of silver benzenesulfonate (15.23 Å)13 and silver p-toluenesulfonate (15.31 Å). Each [Ag2]2+ unit is also bonded to two hydroxyl groups from the adjacent layers to result in a three-dimensional framework structure.

elements.content: The colorless crystals of 2 were obtained by a reaction of AgNO3 with Mg(HL)2 in water. In 2, -SO3H groups are deprotonated, but -OH groups and -CO2H are neutral. There are two kinds of crystallographically unique HL- anions in the structure, and both of them show a similar coordination mode (Figure ). Each sulfonate group binds to three different silver ions, with one oxygen atom binding to two different silver ions, while one oxygen atom binds to only a single silver ion, and the third oxygen atom does not coordinate to the silver atom. Each -CO2H group coordinates to one silver ion, although neutral -CO2H is a weak coordinating group, and the hydroxyl group is not coordinated to a silver ion. Thus, each L2- group binds to four silver ions in all.
elements.clean_text: The colorless crystals of 2 were obtained by a reaction of AgNO3 with Mg(HL)2 in water. In 2, -SO3H groups are deprotonated, but -OH groups and -CO2H are neutral. There are two kinds of crystallographically unique HL- anions in the structure, and both of them show a similar coordination mode (Figure ). Each sulfonate group binds to three different silver ions, with one oxygen atom binding to two different silver ions, while one oxygen atom binds to only a single silver ion, and the third oxygen atom does not coordinate to the silver atom. Each -CO2H group coordinates to one silver ion, although neutral -CO2H is a weak coordinating group, and the hydroxyl group is not coordinated to a silver ion. Thus, each L2- group binds to four silver ions in all.

elements.content: There exist two kinds of crystallographically unique silver ions in 2 (Figures and ). Ag1 is five-coordinated by three sulfonate oxygen atoms from three different HL- groups, one carbonyl oxygen atom and one water molecule, while Ag2 is six-coordinated by three sulfonate oxygen atoms from three different HL- groups and one carbonyl oxygen atom and two water molecules. The distances of Ag1 or Ag2 to neighboring silver ions are larger than 3.8 Å, indicating there is no Ag−Ag binding for them.
elements.clean_text: There exist two kinds of crystallographically unique silver ions in 2 (Figures  and ). Ag1 is five-coordinated by three sulfonate oxygen atoms from three different HL- groups, one carbonyl oxygen atom and one water molecule, while Ag2 is six-coordinated by three sulfonate oxygen atoms from three different HL- groups and one carbonyl oxygen atom and two water molecules. The distances of Ag1 or Ag2 to neighboring silver ions are larger than 3.8 Å, indicating there is no Ag-Ag binding for them.

elements.content: In the structure of 2 (Figure ), each pair of Ag1 ions is bridged by two sulfonate oxygen atoms to form a four-membered ring (Ag2O2), and so is each pair of Ag2. The neighboring Ag1 and Ag2 are connected by a sulfonate group. In all, silver ions are bridged by sulfonate groups to form one-dimensional chains, and each chain is connected to the two neighboring chains through the coordination of the carbonyl oxygen atoms to the silver ions of the neighboring polymeric chain to form a two-dimensional network. The interstitial water molecule (Ow4) in 2 is located between the polymeric layers. Ow4 is hydrogen-bonded to two sulfonate oxygen atoms from different sulfonate anions [Ow(4)···O(26) 2.851 Å; Ow(4)···O(16a) 2.849 Å, symmetry code:  a 1+x, 1+y, 1+z].
elements.clean_text: In the structure of 2 (Figure ), each pair of Ag1 ions is bridged by two sulfonate oxygen atoms to form a four-membered ring (Ag2O2), and so is each pair of Ag2. The neighboring Ag1 and Ag2 are connected by a sulfonate group. In all, silver ions are bridged by sulfonate groups to form one-dimensional chains, and each chain is connected to the two neighboring chains through the coordination of the carbonyl oxygen atoms to the silver ions of the neighboring polymeric chain to form a two-dimensional network. The interstitial water molecule (Ow4) in 2 is located between the polymeric layers. Ow4 is hydrogen-bonded to two sulfonate oxygen atoms from different sulfonate anions [Ow(4)⋅⋅⋅O(26) 2.851 Å; Ow(4)⋅⋅⋅O(16a) 2.849 Å, symmetry code: a 1+x, 1+y, 1+z].

elements.content: In the absorption spectra of 1 and 2, there are two absorption peaks (239 and 306 nm for 1; 244 and 306 nm for 2), due to the K-band and B-band appearing separately. Both of the K-band and B-band correspond to the π → π* transition. The shift of the former absorption from 244 to 239 nm may be caused by the deprotonation of the carboxylic group.
elements.clean_text: In the absorption spectra of 1 and 2, there are two absorption peaks (239 and 306 nm for 1; 244 and 306 nm for 2), due to the K-band and B-band appearing separately. Both of the K-band and B-band correspond to the π → π* transition. The shift of the former absorption from 244 to 239 nm may be caused by the deprotonation of the carboxylic group.

elements.content: Both 1 and 2 show photoluminescence (Figure a,b). The strongest excitation peak for 1 is at 324 nm and that for 2 is 333 nm. Compound 1 shows a main peak at 411 nm with a weak peak at 362 nm, while compound 2 shows a main peak at 422 nm with a shoulder peak at 362 nm, and the main emission band of 2 is broader than that of 1. The Stoke's shifts for 1 and 2 are observed; the emission wavelengths of both 1 and 2 are longer than their absorption wavelengths. The main emission band of 1 and 2 may originate from the π* → π transition of the ligand. Free H2L shows an emission band at 387 nm (Figure c). The coordination of the ligand to the silver center plays an important role in red shift of the emission. The difference between the coordinated ligand (L- and HL-) and the free ligand (H2L) is that the coordinated ligands in 1 and 2 are deprotonated. It is, therefore, conceivable that the removal of the proton from the sulfonic group and carboxylic group decreases the π*−π gap of the ligand, thus resulting in a red shift in emission band. The peak at 362 nm for 1 and 2 is probably due to the L → M charge-transfer transition because there is no emission peak at this position for the free ligand.
elements.clean_text: Both 1 and 2 show photoluminescence (Figure a,b). The strongest excitation peak for 1 is at 324 nm and that for 2 is 333 nm. Compound 1 shows a main peak at 411 nm with a weak peak at 362 nm, while compound 2 shows a main peak at 422 nm with a shoulder peak at 362 nm, and the main emission band of 2 is broader than that of 1. The Stoke's shifts for 1 and 2 are observed; the emission wavelengths of both 1 and 2 are longer than their absorption wavelengths. The main emission band of 1 and 2 may originate from the π* → π transition of the ligand. Free H2L shows an emission band at 387 nm (Figure c). The coordination of the ligand to the silver center plays an important role in red shift of the emission. The difference between the coordinated ligand (L- and HL-) and the free ligand (H2L) is that the coordinated ligands in 1 and 2 are deprotonated. It is, therefore, conceivable that the removal of the proton from the sulfonic group and carboxylic group decreases the π*-π gap of the ligand, thus resulting in a red shift in emission band. The peak at 362 nm for 1 and 2 is probably due to the L → M charge-transfer transition because there is no emission peak at this position for the free ligand.

elements.content: Solid-state photoluminescent spectra of1 (a), 2 (b), and H2L (c) at room temperature.
elements.clean_text: 10  Solid-state photoluminescent spectra of1 (a), 2 (b), and H2L (c) at room temperature.

elements.content: The luminescence decay curves for 1 and 2 (Figure ) can be fitted by an exponential function as I(t) = A exp(−t/τ). The luminescent lifetimes τ are 14.3 μs for 1 and 18.1 μs for 2. The luminescence components are from L2- (1) and HL- (2), respectively. The luminescence lifetimes of 1 and 2 are much shorter than the lifetime of the emission resulted from a triplet state (>10-3s), so the emissions of 1 and 2 should arise from a singlet state.
elements.clean_text: The luminescence decay curves for 1 and 2 (Figure ) can be fitted by an exponential function as I(t) = A exp(-t/τ). The luminescent lifetimes τ are 14.3 μs for 1 and 18.1 μs for 2. The luminescence components are from L2- (1) and HL- (2), respectively. The luminescence lifetimes of 1 and 2 are much shorter than the lifetime of the emission resulted from a triplet state (>10-3s), so the emissions of 1 and 2 should arise from a singlet state.

elements.content: The luminescence decay cures for1 (a, λem = 411 nm) and 2 (b, λem = 422 nm).
elements.clean_text: 11  The luminescence decay cures for1 (a, λem = 411 nm) and 2 (b, λem = 422 nm).

elements.content: In summary, two coordination polymers of Ag(I) with 5-sulfosalicylic acid were synthesized. One of them is the first silver carboxylate-sulfonate with an extended three-dimensional structure and the other shows a two-dimensional polymeric structure that contains a polymeric chain of silver ions and sulfonate groups. Both compounds display photoluminescent properties.
elements.clean_text: In summary, two coordination polymers of Ag(I) with 5-sulfosalicylic acid were synthesized. One of them is the first silver carboxylate-sulfonate with an extended three-dimensional structure and the other shows a two-dimensional polymeric structure that contains a polymeric chain of silver ions and sulfonate groups. Both compounds display photoluminescent properties.

cln_elements.content:
Synthesis of Ag 2 L(H 2 O) (1). To a mixture of H2L (0.11 g, 0.5 mmol) and NaOH (0.040 g, 1.0 mmol) in water (5 mL), a solution of AgNO3 (0.170 g, 1.0 mmol) in water (10 mL) was added. After the sample was stirred for 30 min, the solution was filtered. Colorless crystals of 1 were obtained after the filtrate was left at room temperature for several days. The crystals were collected and washed with water and dried in air (0.16 g). Elemental analysis calcd for C7H6Ag2O7S:  C 18.69, H 1.34; found:  C 18.51, H 1.30. IR (cm-1):  3432 s (-OH), 1562 m (νas CO2), 1436 s (νs CO2), 1034 s (ν3 S−O).

Synthesis of [Ag 2 (HL) 2 (H 2 O) 3 ]H 2 O (2). To a solution of H2L (0.22 g, 1.0 mmol) and MgO (0.020 g, 0.5 mmol) in water (5 mL), a solution of AgNO3 (0.170 g, 1.0 mmol) in water (10 mL) was added. After the sample was stirred for 30 min, the solution was filtered. Colorless crystals of 2 were obtained after the filtrate was left at room temperature for several days. The crystals were collected and washed with water and dried in air (0.27 g). Elemental analysis calcd for C14H18Ag2O16S2:  C 23.29, H 2.51; found:  C 22.91, H 2.40. IR (cm-1):  3408 s (-OH), 1656 m (-CO2H), 1021 s (ν3 S−O).
